Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cannulation Strategies in Aortic Arch Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to either right axillary or innominate artery cannulation.

Participants.evidence: Participants were patients undergoing proximal aortic arch surgery. Eligibility criteria included patients with ATAAD.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received right axillary artery cannulation, while the control group received innominate artery cannulation.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of different cannulation strategies for cerebral protection.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of new severe ischemic lesions, assessed by diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 222 participants were randomised, with 111 in each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The incidence of new severe ischemic lesions was similar between the axillary group (34%) and the innominate group (38.8%).

Harms.evidence: Thirty-day mortality and adverse events, including seizures and delirium, were comparable between groups.
